Recipe.title: Dutch Father's Pizza
Recipe.Description: When I was young, my dad used to cook some wonderful recipes in the Dutch Oven. We were constantly looking for recipes that could be adapted. One year we decided to try pizza and it turned out wonderful. At that time, our favorite was GodFather's Pizza. Some of us commented that it was better than GodFather's. My dad responded, "Of course, it came from a Dutch Oven. It's Dutch Father's Pizza," and the name stuck.

ingredient.name: Pineapple
ingredient.finePrint: Personally, Ransom thinks pineapple is a desecration on pizza, but his kids forced him to include it.

section.title: Sauce
section.instruction: In pot, combine all Sauce Ingredients and simmer for 15 minutes, stirring occationally.

section.title: Crust
section.instruction: Mix Sugar into Water, then add Yeast.
When Yeast begins to foam, add all other ingredients and knead for 10 minutes.
Put in greased bowl, cover and let rise until doubled. (About 30 minutes.)

section.title: Assembling
section.instruction: Line Dutch Oven with foil.
Spread butter all over the bottom and up the edges about 2 inches.
Roll out crust to about ¼ inch thick and about 2-4 inches larger around than Dutch Oven. (There should be enough dough for 2-3 crusts.)
Place in Dutch Oven. Press the edges so they go up the side 1&inch;-2&inch;.
Cover crust with sauce.
Add the toppings desired.
A small layer of Cheese.
Other ingredients desired.
A large layer of Cheese.
Pepperoni on the very top.

section.title: Cooking
section.instruction: On top, put 2 charcol briquettes for each inch in diameter. (For example, 24 briquettes for a 12 inch Dutch Oven.)
The bottom should just be warm. (1 briquette for each 3 inches in diameter. For example, 4 briquettes for a 12 inch Dutch Oven.)
Cook until Cheese has melted then begins to turn golden brown. (20-30 minutes)
Remove all briquettes from the top and place them in a circle just under the edges of the bottom.

Cook until bottom crust begins to brown. (5-10 minutes)
(Check this by pulling up on the foil to lift the edge of the pizza.)
Remove the HOT lid from the Dutch Oven and place it upside down on the table.
You will need to use something to keep the lid level and prevent it from burning the table. (Ransom uses a couple of short pieces of firewood.)
Using the foil, carefully lift the pizza out of the Dutch Oven and set on the lid. (The hot lid will to continue to brown the crust.)
Peel back the foil to expose the edges of the crust.
Use care when serving to make sure all foil is off of the crust.

Notes.note: It is best to make the sauce the night before you use it.
A 2-inch-thick 12&inch; pizza will feed 4 adults (or 2 Boy Scouts. Not Kidding!).

The thicker the pizza, the slower it must be cooked. I made one where each layer of toppings obscured the layer below. It was over 3 inches thick and took over an hour to cook. It sure was good though. &smiley;
CAUTION: The most common problem is over-cooking the bottom.
Use left-over sauce as a dipping sauce for the Pizza crusts.
Use the left-over dough to make "Twisties"
